grounding: The origin of modern eukaryotes is one of the key transitions in life's history, and also one of the least understood. Although the fossil record provides the most direct view of this process, interpreting the fossils of early eukaryotes and eukaryote-grade organisms is not straightforward. We present two end-member models for the evolution of modern (i.e., crown) eukaryotes—one in which modern eukaryotes evolved early, and another in which they evolved late—and interpret key fossils within these frameworks, including where they might fit in eukaryote phylogeny and what they may tell us about the evolution of eukaryotic cell biology and ecology. Each model has different implications for understanding the rise of complex life on Earth, including different roles of Earth surface oxygenation, and makes different predictions that future paleontological studies can test.
generated_text: The early fossil record of eukaryotes, primarily from the Proterozoic Eon, provides critical insights into the origins and early evolution of complex life. This review synthesizes current frameworks for interpreting these fossils, emphasizing the interplay between environmental changes, such as the Great Oxidation Event, and the emergence of eukaryotic lineages. We discuss the morphological and biochemical evidence from microfossils and molecular clocks, highlighting the challenges in distinguishing between prokaryotic and early eukaryotic forms. The integration of geochemical data with paleontological findings suggests that the rise of oxygen played a pivotal role in eukaryogenesis, facilitating the development of more complex cellular structures and metabolic pathways. This multidisciplinary approach offers a robust foundation for understanding the early diversification of eukaryotes and their ecological impacts during the Precambrian.
